results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, Ted captures a trip to Queensland and New South Wales. The film features scenes of holidaying in Queensland, touring around Surfers Paradise, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and Coffs Harbour, before travelling down the East Coast from Sydney to Eden and Lakes Entrance. The film includes memorable scenes such as a show of aqua ballet and water ski stunts in Surfers Paradise, dolphins in the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, historic buildings in Brisbane and fruit farms on the Sunshine Coast.

Of particular interest is Lennon’s Hotel in Broadbeach, which was one of the earliest hotels in Surfers Paradise. At the time, there were few buildings around and the hotel was surrounded by stretches of sand dunes and unsealed roads. It would become the site of the current ‘Oasis Shopping Centre’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 title ‘Queensland Gold Coast 1961’ followed by a sequence where travel brochures are tossed over the title card for hotels and destinations including Brampton Island and Surfers Paradise
00:00:23:00 looking toward Lennon’s Hotel, a very colourful, modern 1960s style roadside hotel
00:00:50:00 sign ‘Welcome to Surfers Paradise’
00:00:55:00 scenes around the pool at the hotel including women sunbaking in bikinis
00:01:32:00 sign ‘KR Darling Downs Bacon’ above a shopping plaza
00:02:37:00 the bridge to Chevron Island in Queensland
00:02:54:00 sign in dry grassland for ‘Shopping Centre Here’
00:03:24:00 handpainted sign for ‘Water Ski Revue and Aqua Ballet’ in Surfers Paradise Gardens
00:03:48:00 scenes of spectators on grassy slopes and the performers on the waterskiing show
00:04:41:00 a woman with a full head of hair ‘curlers’ which was a not uncommon look in the 1960s
00:04:51:00 a woman in costume for the aqua ballet, wearing a blue feathered tutu
00:05:04:00 various waterskiing stunts entertain the appreciative crowd
00:06:22:00 Mount Coot-Tha in Brisbane, a mountain with panoramic views over the city
00:08:14:00 traffic on a main road lined with palm trees
00:09:38:00 view of Brisbane City Hall
00:10:00:00 view of the Queensland National Art Gallery in its former premises on Gregory Terrace where it operated from 1931 to 1974
00:10:25:00 sign for the ‘Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary estd. 1927’
00:10:37:00 a koala riding on the back of a German Shepherd dog, hugging its neck
00:11:35:00 view of the grand sandstone Forgan Smith Building at the University of Queensland

00:13:48:00 fruit farms, including strawberry fields and pineapple groves
00:17:00:00 fruit pickers and workers in the cane fields
00:20:11:00 kite surfer on the river
00:20:57:00 bougainvillea and two women in the gardens
00:22:00:00 banana plants
00:22:37:00 title card ‘Caloundra’
00:22:45:00 exterior of the Reef Hotel
00:23:34:00 large ship arriving on the coast
00:24:02:00 title card ‘Coolangatta’
00:24:05:00 exterior of the Kirra Beach Hotel
00:24:39:00 the Natureland Zoological Gardens
00:28:38:00 swimming and snorkelling with 1950s examples of oxygen tanks
00:29:37:00 exterior view of the George Gilltrap’s Auto Museum with displays of early twentieth century cars and trucks
00:30:48:00 a demonstration of a 1913 fire engine with a group of firemen dressed in uniform, watched by a crowd of onlookers
00:31:50:00 men pumping the fire hose
00:33:40:00 the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, a small aquarium
00:35:07:00 visitors feeding dolphins, leaping up to catch fish from people’s hands
00:37:29:00 sign for ‘Galapagos Island Giant Tortoise’ named Harry
00:38:47:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ across a river
00:38:53:00 rosellas feeding
00:39:16:00 two women feeding rosellas from bowls, birds landing on their heads and arms
00:39:36:00 a toddler screaming as a kangaroo paws its head
00:40:32:00 the Terranora Lakes Country Club Estate with golf course and swimming pool
00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film captures some travels around Victoria. The Parsons take a trip from Wangaratta to Beechworth, down through Mount Buffalo to San Remo and Phillip Island on the south coast, and back up through the Dandenong Ranges and Healesville.

The film shows scenes of life in country towns of Victoria, including sporting and recreational events, the flooding of Ovens River, some beautiful footage of Phillip Island, the Australian Alps in autumn, and the Tesselaar Tulip Festival in Healesville.

The Parsons’ travels also take them to the Hume Dam, formerly known as the Hume Weir, which was a popular tourist destination during the 1940s and 50s.

A feature of the film is the flooded roads and paddocks of Wangaratta during the 1956 floods, which stemmed from major flooding in the Murray River.

Ted films road signs to indicate each stop on their travels.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 road sign ‘Wangaratta Please Slow Down’
00:00:13:00 the Wangaratta Flour Mills building
00:00:20:00 the Wangaratta Woollen Mills
00:00:28:00 swimmers - mostly children - at a water hole or river, and diving off a metal tower
00:01:00:00 a great example of a house with blinds against summer heat and 1950s style car
00:01:15:00 views of gladioli and daisies
00:03:30:00 grasshoppers swarming on the bowls club lawn
00:04:06:00 a man and woman walk with children and an old fashioned baby’s pram followed by children playing in a park playground
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Ovens River’ on a bridge filled with cars
00:04:50:00 1950s style trucks and cars drive through flooded roads
00:05:15:00 flooded paddocks
00:05:33:00 two men, one with two walking sticks, stroll over a bridge closed to traffic in the floods, followed by more views of the floods
00:06:07:00 young women in sports attire walk their bicycles across the bridge
00:06:30:00 scenes of tennis players playing on grass courts to crowds of onlookers, with willow and gum trees in background
00:08:38:00 road sign ‘Beechworth’ followed by views around the township, public gardens, flowers and trees
00:11:20:00 shimmering autumn leaves on a tree, with the trunk being shaken by a grinning friend
00:13:09:00 signpost for Gorge Road and One Tree Hill, a scenic drive and hiking area near Beechworth
00:14:11:00 cypress pine trees on the banks of the gorge
00:14:28:00 picnic beside the car surrounded by gum trees
00:15:24:00 road sign ‘Whitfield Please Slow Down’ followed by views of the surrounding landscape and hills
00:16:30:00 road sign ‘Porepunkah Please Slow Down’
00:17:52:00 Eurobin Falls in Mount Buffalo National Park
00:18:15:00 two women and a man waving from the other side of the waterfalls, water gushing over the rocks beside them
00:19:19:00 a man clambers on to a rock in the rushing water, three women looking on and laughing
00:21:00:00 golden poplar trees and cypress pines in autumn
00:23:48:00 friends on a footbridge, leaning over the railings
00:24:03:00 the same group, joined by another man, posing for the camera on a plank across the river
00:24:30:00 a 1950s style car drives along a country road, golden leaves on the trees
00:25:21:00 roadside picnic featuring great examples of picnic utensils of the period - orange thermoses and baskets
00:27:10:00 road sign ‘San Remo Please Slow Down’ followed by the bridge between San Remo and Phillip Island, Victoria
00:27:28:00 the neon San Remo Hotel sign, followed by brick exterior of the hotel
00:27:52 handpainted sign ‘Nobbies Road House’ followed by the road house on the Nobbies, a headland on Phillip Island
00:28:35:00 1950s style car parked on the shoreline, followed by scenes of the ocean off the headland
00:29:55:00 a wide surf beach with groups of people walking along the shore
00:30:19:00 two women and a men walk up from the shore holding hands
00:30:42:00 man fishing from the beach
00:31:00:00 koalas in a gum tree
00:32:46:00 a snake writhing on the ground, bleeding
00:33:16:00 drinking beer at the kitchen table with great printed curtains behind
00:34:25:00 the Isle of Wight Hotel in Cowes on Phillip Island, Victoria
00:34:46:00 canola flowers
00:36:25:00 a boy letting pigeons out of a cage on the coastline
00:36:56:00 a group of friends walking along the shore, wading in the shallows and playing
00:38:47:00 woman in a printed dress rolls a wooden crate across the sand
00:39:00:00 the group picnic on the beach, sitting on the bonnets of cars parked on the sand
00:39:19:00 grinning man in sunglasses cheers the camera
00:39:41:00 a 1950s emerald green Ford Prefect with touring club badges on the grille arrives at the picnic
00:40:08:00 road signs to Gembrook, Cockatoo and the Princes Highway indicate the Dandenong Ranges in Victoria
00:41:23:00 wooden bridge across the Yarra River
00:42:43 road sign ‘Healesville Please Slow Down’ followed by scenes of the town
00:43:24:00 sign for ‘The Sir Colin Mackenzie Sanctuary’, now the Healesville Sanctuary, followed by scenes of wildlife including emus, kangaroos, pelicans, wallabies, echidnas and peacocks
00:47:06:00 a brown snake with a frog in its mouth
00:51:04:00 close up of a woman’s feet wearing large wooden clogs
00:51:13:00 bunch of tulips in a hand
00:51:20:00 a field of tulips with a woman picking flowers wearing a traditional Dutch costume and spectators watching, at what we can take to be the Tesselaar Tulip Festival, established in 1954 in Healesville and held once a year
00:52:17:00 close up of tulips in the ground
00:54:28:00 sign for the ‘Hume Reservoir’, followed by scenes of the Hume Dam, formerly known as the Hume Weir
00:55:30:00 water rushing down the dam wall
00:57:28:00 people on the edge of the dam wall, watching the water from the top
00:58:24:00 scenes of turbulent water

description_for_label:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film captures some travels around Victoria. The Parsons take a trip from Wangaratta to Beechworth, down through Mount Buffalo to San Remo and Phillip Island on the south coast, and back up through the Dandenong Ranges and Healesville.

The film shows scenes of life in country towns of Victoria, including sporting and recreational events, the flooding of Ovens River, some beautiful footage of Phillip Island, the Australian Alps in autumn, and the Tesselaar Tulip Festival in Healesville.

The Parsons’ travels also take them to the Hume Dam, formerly known as the Hume Weir, which was a popular tourist destination during the 1940s and 50s.

A feature of the film is the flooded roads and paddocks of Wangaratta during the 1956 floods, which stemmed from major flooding in the Murray River.

Ted films road signs to indicate each stop on their travels.

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This films contains scenes at the lawn bowling clubs in and around Wangaratta. As a testament to playing sport or bowls as in this example, the players are older but look very spry and nimble. Also of note, it is not unusual to see players with cigarettes and both players and spectators are very ‘natty’ dressers.

Note that at 00:27:04:00 the film changes to black and white for some minutes and some scenes are repeated.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 sign and gateway for Wangaratta Bowling Club followed by a women’s tournament
00:00:51:00 a great example of bowling and two bowlers smiling at the camera
00:01:01:00 a bowler checks in on a room of tables set for a meal
00:01:47:00 a Californian Bungalow architectural style house in the background
00:02:45:00 bowling toward the camera
00:03:16:00 a cheery smile at the camera
00:03:39:00 men join the bowling green with one bowler encouraging the ball by clicking over his head whilst smoking through a cigarette holder
00:05:05:00 bowlers crossing the green
00:05:54:00 a men’s tournament
00:06:18:00 children and their dog watch the tournament
00:06:31:00 poster for ‘Benalla Bowling Carnival New Year Week-End’ followed by Benalla bowling green and some spectators
00:07:51:00 bowlers refreshing themselves with some beer
00:09:00:00 a crowd dressed for an occasion
00:09:20:00 some dignatories stand in front of bowlers and one of the women bowls what is likely to be an opening shot of the tournament
00:10:10:00 some lovely 1950s style hats worn by members of the watching crowd
00:10:25:00 men’s tournament is underway
00;11:06:00 an old style ‘Smiths’ clock in the clubhouse
00:11:36:00 a man with what might be a ‘press’ or media card in his hat
00:11:56:00 tables set for dining with particularly impressive flower arrangements
00:12:29:00 hats and speeches
00:12:52:00 women’s tournament begins
00:13:02:00 a great shot of all bowlers rolling balls into the centre of the green where the white ball (kitty or jack) sits and congratulating the winner
00:13:47:00 mixed gender tournament followed by views of bowlers at their game
00:16:54:00 the outside of the Wangaratta Club
00:20:24:00 a great example of a men’s knitted vest from the era, worn over a shirt and tie
00:20:37:00 poster for ‘Bowling Carnival Australia Day Week-End’ (1957) followed by a bowling venue with covered seats for spectators
00:21:30:00 a score board
00:22:00:00 a close-up of a laughing bowler smiles at the camera
00:22:10:00 bowlers drinking beers and shooing flies
00:24:30:00 a very agile man with only one leg and a crutch enters the green and uses his crutch to bowl effortlessly
00:25:58:00 the Australian flag flies
00:26:01:00 a bowler, cigarette in his mouth, uses his polishing cloth to clean the ball followed by a double arm amputee, also with cigarette in mouth, who bowls a ball toward the camera
00:27:01:00 bowlers gathered on the lawn cheering and raising their hats
00:30:24:00 lovely old weatherboard buildings in the background of the bowling
00:30:34:00 drinking soft drinks at the club house where one woman bowler puts on a bit of a show for the camera
00:34:48:00 poster for ‘Wangaratta Bowling Carnival Australia Day Week-End’ (1961)
00:36:21:00 a very cheery chap takes his hat off to the camera
00:38:41:00 the Corowa Bowling Club in a garden setting followed by scenes of bowling

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film captures the visit of Australian champion golfer Peter Thomson to the Wangaratta Golf Club in 1956. As shown by the poster in the film, Thomson teaches a golf clinic to an avid crowd. At the time, Thomson had won the British Open twice, and would go on to win it a total of five times - he was the first Australian golfer to win the championship and the only man to have won it in three consecutive years in the twentieth century (1954, 1955 and 1956).

The film shows off the lovely surrounds of the Golf Club set against the backdrop of the town itself and in particular, the backyards of houses. The golfers are particularly smartly dressed in clothes suitable for striding around the course with their golf bags and trolleys, the women in pleated or full mid calf skirts and the men tucking ties into shirts and full 1950s style trousers.

In this film, we can feel the atmosphere of Wangaratta in the post war period - a growing, prosperous community with an increasingly cosmopolitan outlook thanks to an influx of migrants to the area.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Wangaratta Golf Club ‘
00:00:25:00 four golfers appraoching a green wearing stylish golfing clothes of the era
00:01:09:00 golfers shaking hands
00:01:38:00 a particularly nice pink hat on a golfer and an example of the 1950s style golf cart
00:02:09:00 more examples of golfing fashion including sun visors
00:03:19:00 a woman carries her cardigan and bag on her golf cart
00:04:02:00 a closer look at a golf bag in a cart
00:04:27:00 post golf drinks at the clubhouse
00:04:51:00 advertising leaflet for ‘Exhibition Golf and Clinic by Peter Thomson (Dual British Open Champion)’, described as the ‘Greatest Golf Day in History’ followed by scenes of the golf clinic in action
00:04:53:00 a woman with a camera taking shots of Thomson as he conducts the golf clinic
00:05:55:00 views of the large crowd at the golf clinic
00:06:30:00 close-up of Thomson’s golfclubs engraved with his name in protective covers with pom poms
00:06:39:00 a man tees off with a cigarette in his mouth
00:07:00:00 the crowd of onlookers surge forward following a player whlist holding up the boundary rope
00:07:44:00 everyone focused on the player as he lines up a shot
00:08:25:00 Thomson giving lessons on how to grip the golf club in the golf clinic
00:09:45:00 close-up of the crowd
00:11:14:00 local golfers say hello to the camera with lovely old houses behind the golf course
00:12:48:00 a golfer in a 1950s style hat likely to be a ‘Stetson’ and his tie tucked into his shirt leans casually on his golfclub before we see him toss his cigarette stub behind him
00:13:07:00 a refreshment tent set up near the golf course clubhouse with people relaxed
00:13:42:00 ladies and beers at the refreshment tent
00:13:50:00 the camera pans an attentative crowd of onlookers
00:14:47:00 the large crowd follow the play under huge lovely trees on the golf course

This film captures the visit of Australian champion golfer Peter Thomson to the Wangaratta Golf Club in 1956. As shown by the poster in the film, Thomson teaches a golf clinic to an avid crowd. At the time, Thomson had won the British Open twice, and would go on to win it a total of five times - he was the first Australian golfer to win the championship and the only man to have won it in three consecutive years in the twentieth century (1954, 1955 and 1956).

The film shows off the lovely surrounds of the Golf Club set against the backdrop of the town itself and in particular, the backyards of houses. The golfers are particularly smartly dressed in clothes suitable for striding around the course with their golf bags and trolleys, the women in pleated or full mid calf skirts and the men tucking ties into shirts and full 1950s style trousers.

In this film, we can feel the atmosphere of Wangaratta in the post war period - a growing, prosperous community with an increasingly cosmopolitan outlook thanks to an influx of migrants to the area.

description_for_label:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film depicts a trip to the Netherlands and Switzerland, beginning in Welshpool, Wales. It features scenes of “The Dingle” gardens, country fairs, folk dancing, show jumping in Welshpool, Dutch seaside, canal trips in the Netherlands, streetscapes, countryside, farm life, Rotterdam, Spannenburg, bus trip to the Alps, Switzerland, Brienz and Grindenwald.

results.title: [Remix: The Races]
results.creator_credit: Dakota Henderson, ACMI and ACMI Collections
results.brief_description:
This short remix of films about horse racing set to music, takes you through from getting ready and arriving at the track, to placing a bet, the race and the result.

This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to some of the activities around the spring racing carnival that takes place in Melbourne during October and November. It captures the race preparations for both people and horses, and shows the mounting yard, the TAB bets, the race call and a punter finding out the winner.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge donor: Ivan Gaal ( Dir., ‘The Punter’, 1978).

results.title: Glimpses of Australia. [No. 01] [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
Spare a thought for yesteryear as you battle your way through peak hour. This except is from taken from a Commonwealth Government newsreel made in the 1920s. It has been digitised from a 16mm film print and digitally stabilised to improve viewing.
This segment has the intertitle “Melbourne” and shows Melbourne CBD, Flinders St Station, Collins St, trams, trains and Parliament House.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 4 and Reel 5] [excerpts]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

This 9.5mm example is from excerpts of Reels 4 and 5, showing scenes of Jack’s family and friends enjoying their scrambler motor bikes in muddy conditions at Korweinguboora, near Ballarat, Victoria. A group of friends are then shown travelling around the Victorian countryside on motorcycles (motorbikes). Motorcycles have been filmed from a vehicle travelling alongside. The bike riders gather for the camera at the ‘Atlantic Garage’ possibly in Ballarat and then head off for a ride down a dusty country road.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 17. Olympic Pool 1943]  [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This excerpt taken from the complete work on Reel 17, shows people enjoying the water and sunshine at the former State Swimming Centre (now demolished) in Batman Avenue, Melbourne. Being 1943, those enjoying the Olympic-sized pool and its facilities include soldiers in uniform as well as those displaying the various swimwear styles of the 1940s. There are sequences of diving from the high diving-boards, underwater scenes, and people sunbaking, swimming and enjoying themselves. The footage also shows glimpses of landmark buildings of Melbourne at the time, the pool and some of its surrounding seating and walkways. Three landmark Melbourne buildings in the background; St Paul’s Cathedral, the Forum Theatre, and the T&G Building (Temperance and General Building).

The open-air Olympic Pool (formally known as the State Swimming Centre) was built by the Melbourne City Council, and opened in Batman Avenue, Melbourne in 1935. It was Melbourne’s first Olympic-sized pool, and was also known as the Beaurepaire Pool (named after champion swimmer Sir Frank Beaurepaire who was also Melbourne’s Lord Mayor 1940-1942).

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 3. Moomba 1964] [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is an excerpt from Reel 3 showing Melbourne’s Moomba street parade 1964, featuring colourful parade floats, marching girls, musicians and popular personalities of the day. The floats are assembled at the top of Swanston St before they head off for the big parade.
